▿ Step
  ResponseEnded

▿ Request
  GET http://localhost:8080/episodes/ep1-proof-in-functions

▿ Response
  Status 200 OK
  Content-Length: 25914

Date();a=s.createElement(o),m=s.getElementsByTagName(o)[0];a.async=1;a.src=g;m.parentNode.insertBefore(a,m)})(window,document,'script','https://www.google-analytics.com/analytics.js','ga');ga('create', 'UA-106218876-1', 'auto');ga('send', 'pageview');</script></head><body class="bg-dark"><div class="pf-navbar bg-purple px2 lh-4r h-4r between-xs row"><div class=" col"><ul class="list-reset m0"><li class="inline"><a href="/episodes" class="px1">Videos</a></li><li class="inline"><a href="#" class="px1">Blog</a></li><li class="inline"><a href="#" class="px1">Books</a></li><li class="inline"><a href="/about" class="px1">About</a></li></ul></div><div class=" col"><ul class="right list-reset m0"><li class="inline"><a href="/login?redirect=http://localhost:8080/episodes/ep1-proof-in-functions" class="px1">Login</a></li><li class="inline"><a href="/pricing" class="px1">Subscribe</a></li></ul></div></div><div class=" row"><div class=" col col-xs-12 col-md-7"><div class="p4 bg-white"><strong class="h6 caps lh-4">Episode 1</strong><h1 class="h3 lh-2 mt1">Proof in Functions</h1><p><a href="#" class="text-decoration-none bg-light fg-white rounded h6 px1 py1" style="padding-top:0.25rem;padding-right:0.25rem;padding-bottom:0.25rem;padding-left:0.25rem;margin-right:0.25rem">00:00</a>Swift’s generic functions allow us to explore a beautiful idea that straddles the line between mathematics and computer science. If you write down and implement a function using only generic data types, there is a corresponding mathematical theorem that you have proven true. There are a lot of pieces to that statement, but by the end of this short article you will understand what that means, and we will have constructed a computer proof of De Morgan’s law.</p><p><a href="#" class="text-decoration-none bg-light fg-white rounded h6 px1 py1" style="padding-top:0.25rem;padding-right:0.25rem;padding-bottom:0.25rem;padding-left:0.25rem;margin-right:0.25rem">00:30</a>All of the code samples in this article are contained in a Swift playground available for download here.</p><h2 class="h4 lh-3">Generic Functions</h2><p><a href="#" class="text-decoration-none bg-light fg-white rounded h6 px1 py1" style="padding-top:0.25rem;padding-right:0.25rem;padding-bottom:0.25rem;padding-left:0.25rem;margin-right:0.25rem">00:30</a>Let’s start with some exercises to prepare our brains for this kind of thinking. If someone handed you the following function declaration, which doesn’t currently compile, and asked you to fill it out so that it compiles, could you?</p><pre><code class="code swift block p3 overflow-auto-x">func f &lt;A&gt; (x: A) -&gt; A {
    ???
  }</code></pre><p><a href="#" class="text-decoration-none bg-light fg-white rounded h6 px1 py1" style="padding-top:0.25rem;padding-right:0.25rem;padding-bottom:0.25rem;padding-left:0.25rem;margin-right:0.25rem">00:30</a>It’s a function that takes an x in some type A (can be any type) and needs to return something in A. We have absolutely no knowledge of A. No way of constructing a value in that type. For example, we can’t even do something like A() to construct a value, for we have no way of knowing if A has an initializer of that form. Even worse, there’s a chance that A cannot be instantiated, i.e. A has no values! For example, an enum with no cases cannot be instantiated:</p><pre><code class="code swift block p3 overflow-auto-x">enum Empty {
    // no cases!
  }</code></pre><p><a href="#" class="text-decoration-none bg-light fg-white rounded h6 px1 py1" style="padding-top:0.25rem;padding-right:0.25rem;padding-bottom:0.25rem;padding-left:0.25rem;margin-right:0.25rem">00:30</a>This type is valid and compiles just fine, but no instance of it can ever be created. Kind of bizarre, but it will be useful later. Some languages call this type Bottom (⊥).</p><p><a href="#" class="text-decoration-none bg-light fg-white rounded h6 px1 py1" style="padding-top:0.25rem;padding-right:0.25rem;padding-bottom:0.25rem;padding-left:0.25rem;margin-right:0.25rem">00:30</a>So, back to that function f. How can we implement it so that the compiler says everything is A-Ok? Well, we really have no choice but to just return x, i.e. it’s the identity function:</p></div></div><div class="first-xs last-md col col-xs-12 col-md-5"><div class="sticky-md top-0"><video class="fit" controls playsinline autoplay poster="https://d2sazdeahkz1yk.cloudfront.net/assets/W1siZiIsIjIwMTcvMDQvMjgvMDcvMzYvNTAvOTg2ZjI0N2UtZTU4YS00MTQzLTk4M2YtOGQxZDRiMDRkNGZhLzQ3IFZpZXcgTW9kZWxzIGF0IEtpY2tzdGFydGVyLmpwZyJdLFsicCIsInRodW1iIiwiMTkyMHgxMDgwIyJdXQ?sha=318940b4f059d474"><source src=""></video><div class="p2"><div class="mb1 row"><div class=" col col-xs-10"><div><a href="#" class="fg-white text-decoration-none">Generic Functions</a></div></div><div class=" col col-xs-2"><div class="fg-white end-align opacity-75">01:00</div></div></div></div></div></div></div><footer class="row p4 border-top bg-white" style="border-top-color:#ccc"><div class=" col col-xs-12 col-md-6"><div class="pr4"><h4 class="h4 mb0">Point-Free</h4><p>A weekly video series on functional programming and the Swift programming language. Hosted by <a href="https://www.twitter.com/mbrandonw" class="text-decoration-none">Brandon Williams</a> and <a href="https://www.twitter.com/stephencelis" class="text-decoration-none">Stephen Celis</a>.</p></div></div><div class=" col col-xs-4 col-md-2"><div><h5 class="h5">Learn</h5><ol class="list-reset"><li><a href="/episodes">Videos</a></li><li><a href="#">Books</a></li><li><a href="#">Hire Us</a></li></ol></div></div><div class=" col col-xs-4 col-md-2"><div><h5 class="h5">Follow</h5><ol class="list-reset"><li><a href="#">Blog</a></li><li><a href="https://www.twitter.com/pointfreeco">Twitter</a></li><li><a href="https://www.github.com/pointfreeco">GitHub</a></li></ol></div></div><div class=" col col-xs-4 col-md-2"><div><h5 class="h5">More</h5><ol class="list-reset"><li><a href="/about">About</a></li><li><a href="mailto:support@pointfree.co">Email</a></li><li><a href="/terms">Terms</a></li></ol></div></div><div class=" col col-xs-12"><p class="center h6">All videos © Point-Free, Inc.
